content.text: The History of Computing
The First Abacus
The Babylonian Abacus was developed to Reduce the Time to perform calculations.
content.html: The Babylonian Abacus was developed to Reduce the Time to perform calculations.

content.text: As stated in the previous chapter, we believe that the Babylonians invented complex counting.
content.html: As stated in the previous chapter, we believe that the Babylonians invented complex counting.

content.text: The period 2700–2300 BC probably saw the first appearance of an abacus, a table of successive columns which defined the orders of a 60 digits number system.

content.text: The Romans developed the Roman Abacus, a portable, base-10 version of earlier abacuses used by the Babylonians.

content.text: Analog Computers
The Difference Engine (Charles Babbage 1822) was a mechanical machine designed to Reduce the Time to calculate complex mathematical functions.
content.html: The Difference Engine (Charles Babbage 1822) was a mechanical machine designed to Reduce the Time to calculate complex mathematical functions.

content.text: The Analytical Engine (Charles Babbage 1833) was a mechanical machine designed with modern computer elements like arithmetic, logic, and memory.
content.html: The Analytical Engine (Charles Babbage 1833) was a mechanical machine designed with modern computer elements like arithmetic, logic, and memory.

content.text: Digital Computers
Digital Computers use 0/1 switches to perform calculations. They operate on binary values like 11100110 in contrast to analog values like 230.
content.html: Digital Computers use 0/1 switches to perform calculations. They operate on binary values like 11100110 in contrast to analog values like 230.

content.text: The first Electric Digital Computer was designed and built by Konrad Zuse in Germany (1941).
content.html: The first Electric Digital Computer was designed and built by Konrad Zuse in Germany (1941).

content.text: It used 2600 electrical relays as 0/1 switches. The clock speed was about 5 Hz.

content.text: Electronic Computers
First generation Computers (1945-1950) used vacuum tubes as binary switches.
content.html: First generation Computers (1945-1950) used vacuum tubes as binary switches.

content.text: Vacuum tubes are much faster than electrical relays.
content.html: Vacuum tubes are much faster than electrical relays.

content.text: The clock speed of these computers was between 500 KHz and 1 Mhz.
content.html: The clock speed of these computers was between 500 KHz and 1 Mhz.

content.text: Second Generation Computers
Second generation Computers (1950-1960) used transistors as binary 0/1 switches.
content.html: Second generation Computers (1950-1960) used transistors as binary 0/1 switches.

content.text: Transistors are much faster than vacuum tubes.
content.html: Transistors are much faster than vacuum tubes.

content.text: Third Generation Computers
Third generation Computers (1960) used integrated circuits as binary switches.
content.html: Third generation Computers (1960) used integrated circuits as binary switches.

content.text: Integrated circuits are much faster than transistors.
content.html: Integrated circuits are much faster than transistors.

content.text: Computer Speed
The first electrical computer could do 5 instructions per second.
content.html: The first electrical computer could do 5 instructions per second.

content.text: The first electronic computer did 5000 instructions per second.
content.html: The first electronic computer did 5000 instructions per second.

content.text: The first PC did 5 million instructions per second.
content.html: The first PC did 5 million instructions per second.

content.text: AMD was the first PC to reach 1 billion instructions per second.
content.html: AMD was the first PC to reach 1 billion instructions per second.

content.text: Today, IPhone 12 can do 11 billion instructions per second.
